items.description: Jimmy's big, mango-orange flowers are suffused with rose and tipped with gold. The colors change, depending on the light, which makes this tulip fun to watch. It's a good companion for almost any other color, from pink and yellow to purple and blue. Sturdy, long-lasting blooms. A proven performer, first introduced in 1966 by Jan and Adrian Van Hoorn.

items.description: A compact border dahlia with pale yellow flowers that really glow on sunny days. Like other Gallery dahlias, Serenade stands just 2 feet tall, yet it covers itself with big, 4" flowers month after month. The color complements both brights and pastels. Grows well in containers, too.

A perfect choice for any shady place around your home, including windowboxes, patio containers and garden beds.

items.description: Light up a shady garden, porch or patio with this radiant two-tone tuberous begonia. The golden yellow petals are outlined in scarlet red, which gives the flowers a warm glow and accentuates their perfect form. You'll enjoy a continuous parade of blooms from midsummer to frost.

A great choice for windowboxes, edging a shady perennial bed or planting in pots on a deck or patio. Start your own tubers indoors for easy, dependable color from summer to frost.

items.description: This dramatic combination of almost black and pristine white calla lilies makes a lasting impression. Callas are easy to grow in containers or in the garden. Plant the bulbs in spring and by midsummer you can be enjoying their elegant, long-lasting flowers.

It's a masterful blend of color, texture and fragrance, featuring double tulip Crème Upstar along with tulips Angelique and Marilyn, and daffodils Pueblo and Cheerfulness. Just as pretty in the garden as it is in a vase.

items.description: This all-white muscari is as elegant and refined as a string of pearls. Lime green buds open into pure white flowers with a pronounced topknot. Siberian Tiger looks its best when planted in clusters of 12 or more bulbs. It's a must for white gardens!

items.description: This exuberant collection by Alicia Schwede celebrates tulips in every shape and form. There are singles, doubles, and parrots, solids and stripes, in a harmony of purple and burgundy hues. With more than 100 bulbs, you'll have fun creating lots of beautiful arrangements for your home. Striped tulip Flaming Flag will be substituted for Rem's Favorite, which is shown here, but currently unavailable.
items.title: Flower Bulb Assorted Flirty Fleurs Paloma Collection

items.description: Like peaches and cream, this combination of spring flowers is simple, yet immensely satisfying. Floral designer Alicia Schwede told us she was thinking about the sunny coast of Spain when she brought together tulip Mystic Van Eijk, double daffodil Denaslaugh and the fragrant white hyacinth Aiolos. By reflexing some of the tulip petals, which is easy to do, she gave this arrangement a different and contemporary look!

items.description: Two classic peonies that make perfect companions. Buckeye Belle's velvety, burgundy and maroon petals accentuate Festiva Maxima's crisp white perfection. Both are proven performers that will bloom year after year for generations to come.

items.description: Deep and dramatic. Rich and velvety. This sumptuous collection of tulips and hyacinths is all that and more. Floral designer Alicia Schwede has featured the peony-like blooms of double tulip Midnight Magic, plus Black Parrot, Continental and another double tulip, Blue Spectacle. Hyacinth Woodstock adds texture and fragrance.

items.description: A modern dahlia that's been bred for amazing color, sturdy stems and abundant flower production. The luscious, 4-5" blossoms are a tropical blend of peach, mango and papaya with plum-purple highlights. Long, dark purple stems make American Dawn an outstanding cut flower. Guaranteed to be a star in your late summer garden. Note: Unfortunately American Dawn is unavailable for 2019 due to a crop failure. We hope to have it again next year. As a substitute we recommend Great Silence.
items.title: Dahlia Decorative American Dawn

items.description: Artist was one of the world's first viridiflora tulips and it's still among the best. These distinctive flowers have fluted petals that start out carrot-orange with deep green and purple markings. As the blossoms mature, they gradually fade to dusky salmon, olive and lavender. At just under a foot tall, this is a relatively short tulip and ideal for planting at the front of a border or along a walk. Blooms relatively early and lasts two weeks or more.
items.title: Tulip Viridiflora Artist

items.description: A large and lovely iris with very pale, peach-pink petals. Big ruffles and bright orange beards add texture and contrast. The subtle colors of Priscilla of Corinth make it a great choice for areas with part shade rather than full sun. Stands 38-40" tall.
items.title: Bearded Iris  Priscilla of Corinth

items.description: These amazing begonias will fill your hanging baskets and planters with a cascade of non-stop color from summer through fall. Bertini's electrifying red-orange flowers dangle from threadlike stems and almost completely cover the foliage. The plants tolerate a wider range of growing conditions than other begonias, including sun or part shade, heat, humidity and even drought.
items.title: Begonia Upright Double Bertini

items.description: This spiky cactus-style dahlia has pretty rose pink flowers with a glowing yellow center. Karma Pink Corona was bred for the cut flower trade, so you can expect to pick loads of big, 5" blooms on long stems. The compact plants keep gardens colorful long after other perennials have faded.

It's a color combination that pairs beautifully with pink or yellow and looks stunning with purple. Bred for the cut flower market, Karma Corona will give you months of long-stemmed flowers for summer bouquets.
items.title: Dahlia Cactus Karma Corona

items.description:
Seattle-area floral designer Alicia Schwede of Flirtyfleurs.com made this arrangement using Longfield Gardens dahlias grown in her own garden. With a limited palette of harmonious colors and several different flower styles, she composed a distinctive bouquet with an old-world feel. To get the look, simply grow all three varieties in this exclusive collection. Note: Labyrinth (pictured) is unavailable this year, so we are substituting Belle of Barmera.
This may be sold out, but you can still purchase some of the individual varieties that make up this collection by clicking on their links below under "Plant Information"
items.title: Dahlia Assorted Collection Flirty Fleurs Verona

items.description: An heirloom tulip that's been popular for more than 80 years. Red Emperor, also known as Madame Lefebe, has brilliant red, extra large blossoms with a distinctive golden yellow base. As they mature, the flowers open wide and can measure up to 7" across. Always among the first tulips to bloom each spring.

items.description: Welcome Spring's return with this extra-early, brilliant red tulip. Abba's compact height and dependable performance have made it a favorite with landscapers. You can count on it for high voltage color in beds, borders and containers.

items.description: Turn up the color in your spring garden with these vibrant pink and burgundy tulips. Like other Darwin Hybrids, Cosmopolitan has large, deep cups on strong stems. Merlot is a lily-flowered tulip, with flared petals that catch the light. A great look for perennial gardens and good companions for flowering shrubs.
items.title: Tulip Darwin Hybrid Cosmopolitan and Merlot

items.description: Herald Spring's return with this colorful mix of early-blooming crocus. You'll enjoy a tapestry of flowers in purple, lavender, white and yellow. Plant them beneath the shade of mature trees, nestle handfulls of bulbs under shrubs or carpet the ground in a woodland garden.

items.description: These heat-tolerant daffodils perform well in warmer parts of the country where other varieties sometimes struggle. Both produce clusters of sweetly-scented flowers on tall stems. The bright orange cups make them really stand out from a distance.

items.characteristics: Average,Fall,Fall,Fall,Fancy,Green,Indoor Plant,Partial Sun/Shade,Pink,Sun,White,Winter,Winter,Winter
items.description: One of Holland's most popular amaryllis varieties, loved for its rosy color and giant, 8" blossoms. Apple Blossom's snow white petals are brushed with pink and the lime green throat adds a spring-like freshness. Enjoy growing your own fresh flowers this winter!
items.title: Amaryllis Single Apple Blossom

items.description: This stunning collection of late-blooming tulips was developed by Seattle-area florist Alicia Schwede. Alicia grew the tulips in her home garden, then arranged and photographed them and featured the bouquet on her blog, Flirtyfleurs.com. Each variety represents a different style of tulip, to provide variations in texture as well as color. This contemporary mix will look as beautiful in your garden as it does in a vase.

items.description: Lovely, violet-purple petals with a silvery sheen surround a cluster of brilliant orange stamens. An heirloom variety from Holland that's been delighting gardeners for almost 100 years. Multiplies readily in gardens. Also good for planting beneath trees and shrubs or even right in the lawn.
items.title: Crocus Large Flowering Remembrance

items.description: First introduced in the 1940s, Jeanne d'Arc is still the world's best white crocus. Its elegant petals embrace a cluster of brilliant orange stamens. The base of the flower has just a hint of purple. Early, dependable and a good naturalizer.
items.title: Crocus Large Flowering Jeanne D' Arc

items.description: Cheery, early spring flowers that bloom in pretty pastel colors of periwinkle blue, pink and white. The bulbs produce 6 to 10 blossoms each, and they're good naturalizers so you'll enjoy more flowers every year. Easy and dependable. Also known as glory-of-the-snow.

items.description: Perky, daisy-like flowers with sparkling yellow centers. Also known as Grecian windflowers, Anemone blanda is a good naturalizer and will spread a carpet of color beneath shrubs, in perennial gardens or in woodlands. Grows best in soils that are cool and moist in spring and dry during summer when the plants are dormant.
items.title: Anemone Blanda Mixed Blanda

items.description: Snow crocuses bloom even earlier than regular crocuses and have a delicate charm all their own. Miss Vain features pure white petals with just a hint of creamy yellow at the base. On sunny days, the bright orange stamens and golden anthers are irresistible to honeybees.

items.description: This happy little crocus has lots of personality and a unique look that will win your heart. Pickwick's petals are festooned with fancy purple pinstripes. They surround brilliant red-orange stamens that attract bees like a magnet.

items.description: Say goodbye to winter with the first flowers of spring. This colorful mix of purple, yellow and white crocus includes four varieties that perfectly complement each other. They'll multiply happily in perennial gardens, beneath shrubs or even in a lawn, adding cheery color to cool spring days.
items.title: Crocus Large Flowering Assorted Mix

items.description: For dependable late summer color, you can count on this compact, orange-flowered canna lily. items.description: White Splendor's sparkling white blossoms perfectly complement the brilliant blue flowers of Ocean Magic muscari. items.contentAfter:
HOSTA
Hostas are the go-to perennial for shady gardens, and for good reason. They are tough, hardy and will flourish for years with little to no attention. Hosta foliage colors range from creamy white through gold, lime green, medium green and blue-green. Many varieties have variegated leaves and most produce white or lavender flowers in summer. Heights range from 4" to 36" tall.
items.extraContent10:
LAMIUM
This perennial is also known by its common name, dead nettle. It's a low, spreading plant with slightly fuzzy foliage that is usually a mix of green and silver. The late spring to early summer flowers can be purple, pink, red or white. In a shady location, lamium spreads happily -- but usually not invasively. It is also deer resistant. For a similar shade plant with variagated leaves, consider planting pulmonaria, which is more commonly known as lungwort.
items.extraContent5:
HELLEBORE
Hellebores have leathery, evergreen leaves and waxy, rose-like flowers in early spring. These long-lived, carefree plants gradually form large, attractive clumps that are happy to grow in moist or dry soil. Lenten rose (Helleborus niger) is the hardiest and has creamy white flowers in very early spring. Oriental hybrids (Helleborus orientalis) bloom later and have stunning flowers in shades of white, pink, rose and deep maroon. The blossoms are excellent for cutting.
items.extraContent6:
FERN
Most ferns grow best in areas that are cool, damp and shady. There are hundreds of different types to choose from -- so many that you could create a beautiful garden with nothing but ferns. Choose small ferns like the maidenhair fern and Japanese painted fern, or chest-high plants like the ostrich fern. Once established, they need no attention and will return dependably year after year.
items.extraContent7:
GERANIUM
Most perennial geraniums prefer full sun, but some, like Geranium phaeum, is a shade lover. This mounding plant has fuzzy, maple-like leaves that usually display attractive burgundy markings. The wine-red, purple or white flowers are produced on and off all summer long. Geranium macrorrhizum also grows well in light shade. It has fragrant, lime green leaves and hot pink flowers. Heights are 18" to 24".
items.extraContent9:
DICENTRA
Bleeding heart is a long-lived, trouble-free plant with fernlike foliage and dangling, heart-shaped flowers that may be white, pink or red. Dicentra spectablis (old-fashioned bleeding heart) grows 3 feet tall and wide. After it flowers, the foliage dies back to the ground until the following spring. All other types of Dicentra are shorter, flower in summer, and retain their attractive foliage throughout the season.
items.title: 10 Easy Perennials for Shady Gardens
items.unbxd_description: In shady perennial gardens, foliage is just as important as flowers. Combining different leaf textures, shapes and colors adds a new dimension of design opportunities. Discover ten easy-care favorites for the shade.

items.content:
PEONY
Peonies are hardy, long-lived plants that bloom for generations. Most varieties are fragrant and all are wonderful cut flowers. There are hundreds of different varieties of peonies to choose from, with a range of flower styles, colors and bloom times. Peonies are also valued for their foliage, which stays lush and green all season long. These carefree perennials deserve a place in every flower garden.
items.contentAfter:
CLEMATIS
Clematis are climbing vines that will scramble up an arbor or trellis, cascade over a fence or tumble down an stone wall. There are many different flower styles and colors to choose from. Planting two or more varieties of clematis beside each other, will extend the bloom time for a month or more. Some clematis varieties will grow 8 to 10 feet tall, while others grow just 3 to 4 feet tall and are perfect for growing in small spaces or containers.
items.extraContent11:
SEDUM
Sedums are rugged, sun-loving succulents that tolerate both heat and drought. There are many different types. Some hug the ground like a carpet, while others stand up to 3 feet tall. Sedums typically begin blooming in mid to late summer and their flowers persist for months, changing color with the seasons.
To learn more, you may be interested in reading How to Select Perennials for All-Season Color or Planting and Caring for Perennials.
items.extraContent4:
LIATRIS
This North American native plant is also known as blazing star and gayfeather. The wand-like flowers are violet-plum and have a fuzzy texture. The plants grow from corms, and once planted, they return reliably for many years. Liatris are not fussy about soil and they never need staking. The flowers attract bees and butterflies and are excellent for cutting.
items.extraContent5:
DAYLILY
It's hard to go wrong with daylilies. These plants tolerate almost any type of soil, wet or dry. They will grow in hot sun or light shade, and flower for months. Plant breeders have introduced hundreds of daylily varieties with different plant heights and flower styles. Colors now range from almost white through yellow, orange, red, pink and purple. Daylilies are a great choice for difficult areas, yet also a beautiful addition to flower gardens.
items.extraContent6:
ECHINACEA
Plant breeders have turned this native wildflower into a high-performing perennial that's now available in many colors, including white, pink, orange, red and yellow. Echinacea's daisy-like flowers have prominent cones that look attractive even after the petals fall. The flowers attract butterflies and the seedheads are a songbird favorite.
items.extraContent7:
GARDEN PHLOX
Phlox is a classic, summer-blooming perennial with big clusters of sweetly fragrant flowers on sturdy stems. Flower colors range from snowy-white through pink, purple and even orange, with many beautiful bi-colors as well. Phlox is an excellent cut flower and attracts both bees and butterflies.
items.extraContent8:
LILIES
Lilies add color, fragrance and elegance to perennial gardens. Combining several different types of lilies will give you months of blooms. Start with upward-facing Asiatic lilies, followed by trumpet lilies, Oriental-trumpet lilies and Oriental lilies. Lilies are available in a wide assortment of colors and all are long-lasting cut flowers.
items.extraContent9:
RUDBECKIA
This late summer perennial is better known as black-eyed Susan. Its daisy-like flowers have dark brown centers surrounded by golden-yellow petals. Rudbeckia grows almost anywhere, as it's not fussy about soil or moisture. After the flowers fade, the seed-filled centers attract goldfinches and other songbirds. Generally grows about 24" tall.
items.title: 10 Easy Perennials for Sunny Gardens
items.unbxd_description: Sun-loving perennials are the backbone of most flower gardens. Once planted, they return to bloom again each year. Choosing easy-care perennials that are adaptable and long-blooming will give you a colorful garden with the minimum amount of work.

items.title: 5 Tips for Growing Peonies
items.unbxd_description: These lush, early summer flowers are the height of elegance, yet they are also tough as nails. If you?re thinking about planting peonies, here are some tips to help ensure your success.

items.article_title: 6 Tips for a More Colorful Flower Garden
items.content:
Choose Plants With Different Bloom Times
Most people shop for perennials during May or early June, and the most popular plants are the ones that are already in bloom. This means most perennial gardens are filled with early summer flowers such as bleeding heart, peonies, iris and Asiatic lilies. If you want color in mid to late summer, make sure your garden also includes plants such as rudbeckia, sedums, asters and ornamental grasses.
items.extraContent5:
Add Shrubs For Four-Season Interest
Shrubs add structure to flower gardens and can also provide flowers, berries and interesting foliage. Good perennial garden companions include dwarf azaleas and lilacs for springtime blooms, buddleias, clethera and shrub roses for summer flowers, fothergilla, hydrangeas and Japanese maples for fall, and winterberry, Siberian dogwood and witchhazel for winter interest.
items.extraContent6:
Stretch the Color with Bulbs
Planting daffodils, tulips, muscari and other spring-flowering bulbs will fill your garden with color long before your neighbors' gardens are in bloom. Plan to continue the show right through October by adding summer-flowering bulbs such as dahlias, elephant ears, caladiums and eucomis. These heat lovers grow vigorously in summer heat and are at their best as summer turns to fall.
items.title: 6 Tips for a More Colorful Flower Garden
items.unbxd_description: Learn how to add more color to your flower garden and some easy ways to keep that color going all season long.

items.content:
Purchase large bulbs for lots of flowers.
Shop around and purchase the biggest amaryllis bulbs you can find. Jumbo, 34/36 cm bulbs will produce 3 stems with 4 to 5 flowers per stem. Smaller bulbs will give you fewer stems and fewer blossoms.
Keep in mind that some amaryllis varieties naturally produce smaller bulbs than others. Sometimes a 28/30 cm bulb is the largest size available.
items.extraContent6:
Make the most of the flowers.
Depending on the size of the bulb, you can expect 1 to 3 stems, each with 3 to 5 flowers. All of the stems may come out at once, or they may emerge over a period of 2 to 3 weeks.
As with all fresh flowers, cool temperatures will extend their life. Amaryllis also make excellent cut flowers. Cut the stems right before the buds are ready to open, and display them in a vase with greens or other seasonal blooms.
Use scissors to clip off faded blossoms. Once the stem has finished blooming, use a knife to to make a clean cut about 1" above the bulb.
items.summary: Growing an amaryllis requires no special skills. In fact, once a bulb is ready to bloom, it will flower with or without you! But here are a few tips that will help you get the best possible results from these impressive, winter-blooming bulbs.
items.title: 6 Tips for Growing Amaryllis
items.unbxd_description: You don't need a green thumb to grow an amaryllis. But these tips will ensure that you enjoy an impressive performance every time.

items.title: 6 Tips for Growing Clematis
items.unbxd_description: These long-lived perennial vines have an important role in every flower garden. Read on and learn how to be successful with the "queen of climbers."

items.title: 6 Tips for Growing Paperwhite Narcissus
items.unbxd_description: Paperwhite narcissus produce snowy white, sweetly fragrant flowers. The bulbs are easy to grow indoors and will bloom in just 3 to 4 weeks. Here are six tips to ensure your success.
